elements.content: Four new coordination compounds have been obtained by the reaction of copper(II) acetate with SCS [bis(4-pyridylthio)methane], namely, [Cu2(AcO)4(SCS)] (1), [Cu2(AcO)4(SCS)]·solv (2), [Cu4(AcO)8(SCS)5(H2O)6]·4H2O (3), and [Cu4(OH)2(AcO)6(SCS)2]·10H2O (4). Structural diversity is achieved by the copper acetate moiety in combination with the flexibility of the SCS ligand. X-ray structural analysis revealed that the compounds have different structural motifs: linear chains in 1, zigzag chains in 2, undulated tetramers in 3, and ladder-like chains in 4. The structures are further connected through hydrogen-bonding interactions with trapped solvent molecules in the crystal lattices (2–4). Guest molecules have a decisive influence on the final crystal system for 2–4. Compound 2 exhibits a temperature-induced single-crystal to single-crystal (SC–SC) transformation, and phase transitions from 2 and 3 to 1 have been found in an irreversible desolvation or recrystallization process.

elements.content: Structural diversity in four new coordination compounds based on the copper(II) acetate/bis(4-pyridylthio)methane system is observed. Temperature-induced SC−SC polymorphic phase transformation and other phase transitions to the stable guest free form are also found.

elements.content: The search for rational control over the preparation of metal–organic coordination compounds is of increasing interest in the scientific community, especially in inorganic and materials chemistry, due to the chemical and physical properties of this class of materials. Nevertheless, this control continues to be a challenge for the synthetic chemist because the final structure depends on many factors, such as the coordination ability of the metal center, the nature of the ligands or counteranions used, and the experimental conditions.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The search for rational control over the preparation of metal-organic coordination compounds is of increasing interest in the scientific community, especially in inorganic and materials chemistry, due to the chemical and physical properties of this class of materials. Nevertheless, this control continues to be a challenge for the synthetic chemist because the final structure depends on many factors, such as the coordination ability of the metal center, the nature of the ligands or counteranions used, and the experimental conditions.

elements.content: The predominant synthetic strategy used in the development of specific metallosupramolecular architectures is the node and linker approach. Metal-containing secondary building units (SBUs) are commonly used as network nodes due to the wide array of available geometries.
elements.clean_text: The predominant synthetic strategy used in the development of specific metallosupramolecular architectures is the node and linker approach. Metal-containing secondary building units (SBUs) are commonly used as network nodes due to the wide array of available geometries.

elements.content: The vast majority of coordination polymers include single metal centers linked by a huge variety of ligands. However, in some studies coordination compounds are obtained from bridging ligands linked by metal clusters. The copper(II) acetate dimer is one of the simplest imaginable cluster species, and it has the potential to provide an effectively linear link between donors. Nevertheless, copper(II) acetate is frequently used as a source of metal atoms, and few examples are known in which the metal acetate dimers are connected in a 1D chain.

Nevertheless, copper(II) acetate is frequently used as a source of metal atoms, and few examples are known in which the metal acetate dimers are connected in a 1D chain.

elements.content: The combination of ditopic linker ligands and copper carboxylate units produces coordination networks of high dimensionality. Among this kind of ligand, our group has previously investigated the interaction of the Cu(II) cation with the N,N-divergent twisted bis(4-pyridylthio)methane (SCS) ligand. The structural results obtained with several carboxylate ligands showed that this combination of ligands produces metal complexes that range from molecular to coordination polymers of diverse dimensionality.

The structural results obtained with several carboxylate ligands showed that this combination of ligands produces metal complexes that range from molecular to coordination polymers of diverse dimensionality.

elements.content: The SCS ligand shows flexibility associated with the S–C–S bonds, and this allows a characteristic twisted shape that, in combination with the geometry of the metal node, gives rise to structurally diverse coordination polymers. The flexible ligands in coordination polymers can exhibit multiple conformation modes, but it is rare to find more than one conformation in any given polymer network. Conformationally flexible ligands are expected to exhibit polymorphism as well as supramolecular isomerism, and this would lead to coordination polymers with diverse topologies in the solid state.

elements.content: In the SCS ligand, it is possible to distinguish different conformers, with the GG form being predominant along with a smaller contribution from the TG form in the conformational mixture. In both cases, it is possible to distinguish the two forms with opposite helicity, that is, the right-handed P- and the left-handed M-forms.

elements.content: The supramolecular isomerism phenomenon has found considerable application in materials science in recent years due to its contribution to the study of supramolecular chemistry and the structure–property relationships of functional materials. Of particular interest are the crystalline forms that differ in the nature or stoichiometry of included solvent molecules. The inclusion of solvent molecules in the crystallization process takes place within the crystal lattice and makes the phenomenon even more complicated and, at the same time, interesting. These phenomena appear more frequently when more flexible systems and more functional groups are involved. However, the investigation of these phenomena could further enlighten the thermodynamics and kinetics of crystal growth, crystal packing, and solid state transformations.

elements.content: The aim of the work described here was to investigate the solid state coordination chemistry of Cu(II) acetate with the flexible twisted ligand SCS under different synthetic conditions. We report the synthesis and structural study of four new copper(II) compounds. The role in the crystal packing of the weak intermolecular interactions, the solvent molecules hosted within the crystal lattices, and the solid state transformation of 2a to 2b and 2 or 3 to 1 is also analyzed.

elements.content: Bis(4-pyridylthio)methane (SCS) was prepared as described previously. The other starting materials and solvents were obtained commercially and were used as supplied. Elemental analyses (C, H, N, S) were carried out on a Fisons EA-1108 microanalyzer. IR spectra were recorded from KBr discs (4000–400 cm–1) on a Bruker Vector 22 spectrophotometer. TGA was performed on a SETSYS Evolution Setaram thermogravimetric analyzer in a flow of N2.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Procedures

Materials and Physical Measurements

Bis(4-pyridylthio)methane (SCS) was prepared as described previously. The other starting materials and solvents were obtained commercially and were used as supplied. Elemental analyses (C, H, N, S) were carried out on a Fisons EA-1108 microanalyzer. IR spectra were recorded from KBr discs (4000-400 cm-1) on a Bruker Vector 22 spectrophotometer. TGA was performed on a SETSYS Evolution Setaram thermogravimetric analyzer in a flow of N2.

elements.content: A solution of SCS (1 mmol) in methanol (10 mL) was added slowly to a suspension of Cu(AcO)2·H2O (1 mmol) in methanol (10 mL). The suspension was heated under reflux for 3 h. The resulting green precipitate was filtered off, washed with methanol, and dried under vacuum. Single crystals were obtained by slow evaporation at rt (1 week) of the mother liquor and also by slow diffusion in a test tube of a solution of SCS (0.25 mmol) in ethanol (3 mL) and a solution of Cu(AcO)2·H2O (0.5 mmol) in water (5 mL) at rt. The powder X-ray diffraction data were compared with those simulated from the crystal structure and showed that the crystal is representative of the bulk material. Data for 1 from the first synthetic procedure. Yield: 75%. Anal. Calcd for C19H22N2S2O8Cu2: C 38.2, H 3.7, N 4.7, S 10.7%. Found: C 38.2, H 3.5, N 4.7, S 10.9%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3437m, 1616s, 1588m, 1486m, 1422m, 1211m, 1072m, 804m, 736m, 498m.

The resulting green precipitate was filtered off, washed with methanol, and dried under vacuum. Single crystals were obtained by slow evaporation at rt (1 week) of the mother liquor and also by slow diffusion in a test tube of a solution of SCS (0.25 mmol) in ethanol (3 mL) and a solution of Cu(AcO)2⋅H2O (0.5 mmol) in water (5 mL) at rt. The powder X-ray diffraction data were compared with those simulated from the crystal structure and showed that the crystal is representative of the bulk material. elements.content: Crystallographic data for 1, 2b, 3, and 4 were collected on a Bruker Smart 1000 CCD diffractometer using graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data for 2a were obtained at 100 K, and data for the determination of the unit cell at room temperature were collected on a microfocal Bruker Smart 6000 CCD diffractometer using graphite monochromated Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å). All data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects.
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

Crystallographic data for 1, 2b, 3, and 4 were collected on a Bruker Smart 1000 CCD diffractometer using graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data for 2a were obtained at 100 K, and data for the determination of the unit cell at room temperature were collected on a microfocal Bruker Smart 6000 CCD diffractometer using graphite monochromated Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å). All data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects.

elements.content:
The frames were integrated with the Bruker SAINT software package, and the data were corrected for absorption using the program SADABS.

The structures were solved by direct methods using the program SHELXS97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters by full-matrix least-squares calculations on F 2 using the program SHELXL97. Hydrogen atoms were inserted at calculated positions and constrained with isotropic thermal parameters, except for the hydrogen atoms of the crystallization water molecules of 4, which were located from a difference Fourier map. Drawings were produced with MERCURY, and special computations for the crystal structure discussions were carried out with PLATON.

elements.content: Four new compounds based on the Cu(II) acetate/SCS twisted N,N-ligand system were obtained by adjusting the synthetic conditions (Scheme ). Compounds were isolated from reactions carried out under mild conditions with 1:1 or 2:1 metal/ligand ratios using alcoholic solvents and water as the main solvents in four different synthetic methods, that is, under hydrothermal conditions (3), microwave irradiation (2), reflux synthesis (1), or slow diffusion in test tubes (4, 1, and 3).
elements.clean_text:
Results

Synthesis and Spectroscopic Characterization

Four new compounds based on the Cu(II) acetate/SCS twisted N,N-ligand system were obtained by adjusting the synthetic conditions (Scheme ). Compounds were isolated from reactions carried out under mild conditions with 1:1 or 2:1 metal/ligand ratios using alcoholic solvents and water as the main solvents in four different synthetic methods, that is, under hydrothermal conditions (3), microwave irradiation (2), reflux synthesis (1), or slow diffusion in test tubes (4, 1, and 3).

The use of a 1:1 molar ratio (M/L) led to compound 1 and solvate 2. Compound 1 was obtained under reflux using methanol as the solvent, whereas the solvate 2 was prepared by microwave irradiation using dimethylformamide and ethanol as solvents. The use of microwave irradiation has proven to be an interesting tool in this kind of system for the isolation of pure compounds in very short reaction times, as found here in the preparation of 2.

elements.content: The use of a 2:1 molar ratio (M/L) led to compounds 3 and 4. Hydrothermal conditions (110 °C) allowed the isolation of the pure phase 3, whereas 4 was obtained in a slow diffusion process using acetonitrile and water as solvents, and this compound took a longer time to crystallize. The basic reaction medium allowed the formation of a stable cluster node in 4 by the incorporation of the OH– species. This kind of cluster has been detected previously in a coordination polymer obtained from reactions of copper(II) acetate and formate with the 4,4′-dipyridyldisulfide ligand.

The basic reaction medium allowed the formation of a stable cluster node in 4 by the incorporation of the OH- species. This kind of cluster has been detected previously in a coordination polymer obtained from reactions of copper(II) acetate and formate with the 4,4'-dipyridyldisulfide ligand.

elements.content: The use of microwave radiation is crucial to obtain compound 2, whereas the other compounds can be isolated at rt after slow diffusion processes. This fact reveals that despite the difficulty in controlling the different parameters that govern the diffusion, the molar ratio and the solvent are the main factors to consider for the isolation of three of the compounds.

elements.content: The lack of control over the crystallization process can lead to the simultaneous formation of different phases. In this respect, it is interesting to note that none of the synthetic conditions used in this work led to a mixture of compounds, despite the fact that all of the products were obtained from the same building blocks. Even when slow diffusion gave compounds 1 and 3 in the same test tube, it was possible to separate the two compounds easily since 3 (blue crystals) appeared in the middle-bottom of the tube and green crystals of 1 were formed in the middle-top, in the alcoholic medium with a higher concentration of the SCS ligand. In the bottom of the tube, the concentration of water and the metal salt precursor was higher than in the top, and consequently, the synthetic conditions promoted the formation of 3 ().

elements.content: The FT-IR spectra of the compounds display features corresponding to chelating modes of acetate and the characteristic absorption bands of the SCS ligand. The infrared spectra show medium-intensity broad bands around 3420–3440 cm–1 corresponding to OH stretching vibrations of the crystallization water molecules. The spectrum of complex 2 displays a ν(CO) band at 1680 cm–1 due to the dmf solvent molecules present in the framework. In vibrational spectroscopic studies of acetate complexes, the difference (Δν) between νasym(CO2 –) and νsym(CO2 –) bands is often used to draw conclusions about the type of carboxylate coordination. In this study, we attempted to make a correlation between the COO– stretching frequencies and the types of acetate coordination. Data for the symmetric and antisymmetric stretching frequencies for acetate and Δνa–s are listed in Table S3, . The frequency separations (Δνa–s) for the unidentate, bidentate, and ionic species are usually in the following order: Δνa–s (unidentate) > Δνa–s (ionic) > Δνa–s (bidentate). As described below in the section (vide infra), the compounds described here contain acetate ligands that have different coordination modes. Compounds 1, 2 and 2·desolvated, with the acetate acting as a bridging ligand, show Δνa–s values that are slightly lower than that of 3, where the acetate acts as a unidentate ligand. In contrast, compound 4, in which the acetate ligands have three coordination modes (bridging, unidentate, and bidentate), has slightly lower values than the other compounds.

The spectrum of complex 2 displays a ν(CO) band at 1680 cm-1 due to the dmf solvent molecules present in the framework. In vibrational spectroscopic studies of acetate complexes, the difference (Δν) between νasym(CO2 -) and νsym(CO2 -) bands is often used to draw conclusions about the type of carboxylate coordination. In this study, we attempted to make a correlation between the COO- stretching frequencies and the types of acetate coordination. Data for the symmetric and antisymmetric stretching frequencies for acetate and Δνa-s are listed in Table S3, . The frequency separations (Δνa-s) for the unidentate, bidentate, and ionic species are usually in the following order: Δνa-s (unidentate) > Δνa-s (ionic) > Δνa-s (bidentate). As described below in the  section (vide infra), the compounds described here contain acetate ligands that have different coordination modes. Compounds 1, 2 and 2⋅desolvated, with the acetate acting as a bridging ligand, show Δνa-s values that are slightly lower than that of 3, where the acetate acts as a unidentate ligand. In contrast, compound 4, in which the acetate ligands have three coordination modes (bridging, unidentate, and bidentate), has slightly lower values than the other compounds.

elements.content: All of the compounds described here were isolated as single crystals and their X-ray structures were determined. Significant structural parameters for compounds 1–4 are listed in Table , and crystal structure and refinement data are listed in Table . The four metal complexes can be considered as supramolecular isomers since they are generated from the same building blocks, that is, copper(II) as the metal center, acetate, and the SCS bispyridine ligand. It was envisaged that the combination of the linear bidentate ligand with linear metallic units would result in the formation of 1D coordination polymer chains (1 and 4), but it was not expected that the arrangement of such units in the solid state may produce a channel-containing material (2) or a stable tetramer (3). The metal centers appear to be located in a square pyramidal geometry or in an axially elongated octahedral geometry in 4 and 3 (Cu2), with this being the least flexible unit in the structures. It is therefore apparent that the flexibility of the coordination environment of the copper center is not essential to achieve the structural diversity observed in this system.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Studies

All of the compounds described here were isolated as single crystals and their X-ray structures were determined. Significant structural parameters for compounds 1-4 are listed in Table , and crystal structure and refinement data are listed in Table . The four metal complexes can be considered as supramolecular isomers since they are generated from the same building blocks, that is, copper(II) as the metal center, acetate, and the SCS bispyridine ligand. It was envisaged that the combination of the linear bidentate ligand with linear metallic units would result in the formation of 1D coordination polymer chains (1 and 4), but it was not expected that the arrangement of such units in the solid state may produce a channel-containing material (2) or a stable tetramer (3). The metal centers appear to be located in a square pyramidal geometry or in an axially elongated octahedral geometry in 4 and 3 (Cu2), with this being the least flexible unit in the structures. It is therefore apparent that the flexibility of the coordination environment of the copper center is not essential to achieve the structural diversity observed in this system.

As expected the N,N-divergent SCS ligand allowed polymerization through coordination bonds, but this polymerization is unexpectedly disrupted in 3. The twisted SCS ligand provides the flexibility to generate different topologies, from a linear chain in 1 to zigzag chains in 2 and 4 (Table ). This flexibility also allows the formation of cavities that are large enough to accommodate guest solvent molecules in compound 2. This approach of introducing flexibility into the ligand linker, which allows the modulating effect in the framework, is different from the more common transformation effect approach in which the geometry changes at the SBU–ligand.

The twisted SCS ligand provides the flexibility to generate different topologies, from a linear chain in 1 to zigzag chains in 2 and 4 (Table ). This flexibility also allows the formation of cavities that are large enough to accommodate guest solvent molecules in compound 2. This approach of introducing flexibility into the ligand linker, which allows the modulating effect in the framework, is different from the more common transformation effect approach in which the geometry changes at the SBU-ligand.

elements.content: The acetate ion is one of the smallest and simplest carboxylate ligands, and the number and variety of coordination modes of the acetate ligand observed in this work (Table ) allowed the formation of different nodes, including mono- (3), bi- (1 and 2), and tetranuclear (4) units.
elements.clean_text: The acetate ion is one of the smallest and simplest carboxylate ligands, and the number and variety of coordination modes of the acetate ligand observed in this work (Table ) allowed the formation of different nodes, including mono- (3), bi- (1 and 2), and tetranuclear (4) units.

elements.content: Compounds 1 and 2 result from solution-phase synthesis starting from the same paddle-wheel synthons to give 1D polymers that have a different final 3D arrangements depending on the synthetic conditions. The use of Cu2(AcO)4 as a metal node for organic–inorganic coordination polymers is well documented and numerous dinuclear −Cu2(AcO)4– or mononuclear −Cu(AcO)2– containing organic/inorganic complexes have been reported to date. However, it is interesting to highlight that one-dimensional coordination polymers based on the units {−Cu2(AcO)4–Cu2(AcO)4−} have not been as extensively explored.
elements.clean_text: Compounds 1 and 2 result from solution-phase synthesis starting from the same paddle-wheel synthons to give 1D polymers that have a different final 3D arrangements depending on the synthetic conditions. The use of Cu2(AcO)4 as a metal node for organic-inorganic coordination polymers is well documented and numerous dinuclear -Cu2(AcO)4- or mononuclear -Cu(AcO)2- containing organic/inorganic complexes have been reported to date. However, it is interesting to highlight that one-dimensional coordination polymers based on the units {-Cu2(AcO)4-Cu2(AcO)4-} have not been as extensively explored.

elements.content: Compounds 1 and 2 could be considered pseudopolymorphs since they have the same crystalline form but 2 crystallizes with guest solvent molecules hosted within the supramolecular cavities. Polymorphism is rare in the field of coordination chemistry because it can be defined as the existence of the same chemical substance in more than one crystalline form, and few examples are reported in the literature. Moreover single crystal to single crystal polymorphic phase transition is even stranger. This kind of crystal transformation is usually induced by light, temperature, or mechanical forces. Compound 2 crystallizes in the orthorhombic Pnma space group at 100 K (2a) and in the monoclinic C2/c space group at room temperature (2b). In order to confirm this fact, the unit cells of the same single crystal were measured at 100 and 273 K, and it was found that 2a undergoes a single-crystal to single-crystal transformation on changing the temperature.

Polymorphism is rare in the field of coordination chemistry because it can be defined as the existence of the same chemical substance in more than one crystalline form, and few examples are reported in the literature. Moreover single crystal to single crystal polymorphic phase transition is even stranger. This kind of crystal transformation is usually induced by light, temperature, or mechanical forces. Compound 2 crystallizes in the orthorhombic Pnma space group at 100 K (2a) and in the monoclinic C2/c space group at room temperature (2b). In order to confirm this fact, the unit cells of the same single crystal were measured at 100 and 273 K, and it was found that 2a undergoes a single-crystal to single-crystal transformation on changing the temperature.

elements.content: The difference between 2a and 2b is not only the greater disorder of the solvent molecules at rt but also the flexibility of the bonds in SCS leading to different structural changes (vide infra). Both phases are clearly distinguished by the cell parameter values, differing significantly in the β angle, which is reflected in the variation of the cell volume of 54 Å3. This transformation from the low temperature to rt is accompanied by an expansion of all unit cell parameters. The integrity of the single crystal was completely preserved under such transformation conditions, as the recorded diffraction patterns of single crystals indicate. We have found in the literature some examples of polymorphic phase transformations under different stimuli with changes in the unit cell in the same order as in the case here described (Table S5, ).

elements.content:
The conversion of 2 to 1 upon loss of solvent requires soaking with a less polar solvent and a postheating treatment to remove the crystallization solvent and initiate the conversion.

Six coordination polymers obtained by reaction of copper(II) formate and acetate salts with the twisted 4,4′-dipyridyldisulfide ligand (SS) have been described, and two of them, {[Cu4(HCO2)6(OH)2(SS)2]·2CH2Cl2} n and {[Cu4(AcO)6(OH)2(SS)2]} n , contain carboxylate ions with the same structural motif as in 4. Nevertheless, 4-pyridylsulfonate ions are formed as result of the oxidative cleavage of the disulfide group of the SS ligand in three of these compounds. The complexes described in this work can be considered to provide evidence of the better stability of the S–C–S bridge bond of the SCS ligand compared with the higher reactivity of the S–S bond of the SS ligand.

The conversion of 2 to 1 upon loss of solvent requires soaking with a less polar solvent and a postheating treatment to remove the crystallization solvent and initiate the conversion.

Six coordination polymers obtained by reaction of copper(II) formate and acetate salts with the twisted 4,4'-dipyridyldisulfide ligand (SS) have been described, and two of them, {[Cu4(HCO2)6(OH)2(SS)2]⋅2CH2Cl2} n  and {[Cu4(AcO)6(OH)2(SS)2]} n , contain carboxylate ions with the same structural motif as in 4. Nevertheless, 4-pyridylsulfonate ions are formed as result of the oxidative cleavage of the disulfide group of the SS ligand in three of these compounds. The complexes described in this work can be considered to provide evidence of the better stability of the S-C-S bridge bond of the SCS ligand compared with the higher reactivity of the S-S bond of the SS ligand.

elements.content: Selected structural parameters are listed in Table , and the coordination environment of the copper atom is shown in Figure . These complexes, as polymorphs or pseudopolymorphs, have the same covalent architecture, and they will therefore be described together. Compound 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅, whereas in 2 the inclusion of the solvent molecules increases the symmetry in two different phases depending on temperature: the monoclinic C2/c phase 2a observed at rt and the orthorhombic Pnma phase 2b observed at 100 K. Both compounds consist of 1D chains in which the paddle-wheel clusters are linked by bridging SCS ligands with the four bidentate acetate ligands occupying the basal sites of the coordination polyhedra (Figure ). Cu(II) atoms are distributed among one complete Cu2(AcO)4 group located at an inversion center in the three structures. From the morphology of the typical dinuclear core {Cu2(O2–C–CH3)4}, the axial site provides a feasible place for the coordination of the SCS linker. Each copper atom is (NO4) pentacoordinated with Addison parameter values (Table ) that are consistent with a square pyramidal geometry. Four oxygen atoms belonging to four different acetate ligands are in the basal positions, and the SCS nitrogen atom is in the apical position, with Cu–N distances of 2.169(6) Å in 1 and 2.177(6) Å in 2a and 2b. The formation of this paddle-wheel unit favors shorter Cu–Cu distances, which are very similar in all compounds [2.627(16) Å in 1, 2.6141(19) Å in 2a, and 2.6353(18) Å in 2b] and also similar to those observed previously. Acetate acts as a syn–syn bidentate bridging ligand (μ2-κ1:κ1) in all compounds.

Structural study of Compounds 1 and 2 

Selected structural parameters are listed in Table , and the coordination environment of the copper atom is shown in Figure . These complexes, as polymorphs or pseudopolymorphs, have the same covalent architecture, and they will therefore be described together. Compound 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅, whereas in 2 the inclusion of the solvent molecules increases the symmetry in two different phases depending on temperature: the monoclinic C2/c phase 2a observed at rt and the orthorhombic Pnma phase 2b observed at 100 K. Both compounds consist of 1D chains in which the paddle-wheel clusters are linked by bridging SCS ligands with the four bidentate acetate ligands occupying the basal sites of the coordination polyhedra (Figure ). Cu(II) atoms are distributed among one complete Cu2(AcO)4 group located at an inversion center in the three structures. From the morphology of the typical dinuclear core {Cu2(O2-C-CH3)4}, the axial site provides a feasible place for the coordination of the SCS linker. Each copper atom is (NO4) pentacoordinated with Addison parameter values (Table ) that are consistent with a square pyramidal geometry. Four oxygen atoms belonging to four different acetate ligands are in the basal positions, and the SCS nitrogen atom is in the apical position, with Cu-N distances of 2.169(6) Å in 1 and 2.177(6) Å in 2a and 2b. The formation of this paddle-wheel unit favors shorter Cu-Cu distances, which are very similar in all compounds [2.627(16) Å in 1, 2.6141(19) Å in 2a, and 2.6353(18) Å in 2b] and also similar to those observed previously. Acetate acts as a syn-syn bidentate bridging ligand (μ2-κ1:κ1) in all compounds.

elements.content: Taking into account the structural parameters, dimetal cores present similar values in the three structures. Thus, it is the SCS linker that extends the polymerization in a linear or sinusoidal way and, consequently, leads to the different supramolecular arrangements in compounds 1 and 2. Each SCS ligand adopts a μ2-bridging mode that connects paddle-wheel centers and triggers the shape of the chains, from strictly linear in 1 to zigzag in 2.

elements.content: The intermetallic distances through the SCS-bridge are 14.5 Å for compound 1 and 13.1 and 14.5 Å for the 2a and 2b phases, respectively. Moreover, the intramolecular N···N distance is shorter in 2a (9.8 Å) than in 1 (10.2 Å) or 2b (10.5 Å). The SCS ligand acts as a semirigid ligand, and it shows flexible behavior with the same connectivity and geometry environment. The twisting mechanism only takes places in the ligand, and it is able to pull the compound open (Figure ). There are some structural parameters that allow the ligand to curve outward due to the presence of the guest molecules. This curvature is reflected in the value of the angle between the planes defined for the pyridine rings of 43.14° (2a), 42.93° (2b), and 0° in 1 or in the C–C–S–C torsion angle, which changes from 140.9(10)°/39.5(11)° in 1 to 160.7(6)°/19.4(8)° in 2a (Table ).

elements.content: In accordance with this situation, the value of the C–S–C–S torsion angle in 2a is 165.7(5)° and in 2b it is 139.9(8)°, the largest found in SCS systems to date and far from that in the free ligand [73.73(7)°]. This corresponds to an AA conformation, and it is the first time that such an angle has been observed in this type of ligand. The disorder of the methylene group −CH2– through two possible positions in 1 makes the structure achiral, and it is difficult to determine the exact C–S–C–S angle, which has an average value of 97.62°. In 2a and 2b, each chain is achiral and incorporates molecules of SCS with opposite helicity. In contrast, this alternation of the two possible enantiomeric configurations (M and P) in the chains allows the presence of guest solvent molecules in the voids formed in the metal–organic frameworks of 2a and 2b. The absence of solvent molecules allows the formation of linear chains that extend along the [2 1 –1] direction in 1. Each chain interacts with the adjacent ones by means of C–H···O(AcO) interactions (Table ) in the ab plane (Figure ), and they are arranged in a shifted parallel manner with a distance between adjacent chains of approximately 4.1 Å (calculated from the planes defined by the SCS pyridine rings) (Figure ). Consequently, the structural elements are packed very efficiently in 1, as evidenced by the calculated density of 1.702 g cm–3.

elements.content: In 2b, the sinusoidal chains extend along the [1 0 –1] direction and are arranged in a parallel manner, with no shift in the arrangement compared with 1, and the solvent molecules are hosted in suitable cavities in the ab plane (Figure ). Weak C–H···O(AcO) interactions are established between adjacent chains in 2b, but as observed in 2a and similar compounds, solvent molecules are involved in different interactions with the metal–organic framework, and this contributes to the stability of the structure. Intermolecular interactions with the solvent molecules seem to play an important role in the supramolecular association. The crystallographically independent dmf and water molecules are associated by C–H···Ow interactions (Table ). Weak C–H···O(solvent) interactions (Table ) anchor the solvent molecules to the metallorganic chains. Hydrogen-bonding interactions are established with the SCS ligand, but there are no significant interactions with the paddle-wheel Cu2(AcO)4 unit. The ligand points the pyridine and methylene hydrogens toward the center of the voids, thus allowing the formation of two seven-membered rings (Figure ).

elements.content: Selected structural parameters are listed in Table and the different coordination environments of the copper ions are shown in Figure . The compound crystallizes in the C2/c space group with two crystallographically independent copper atoms. elements.clean_text:
Structural Study of Compound 3 

Selected structural parameters are listed in Table  and the different coordination environments of the copper ions are shown in Figure . The compound crystallizes in the C2/c space group with two crystallographically independent copper atoms. Compound 3 is a zigzag tetramer based on four copper(II) metal centers coordinated by a terminal acetate, five SCS ligands, and water molecules involved in coordination with the metal. Crystallization water molecules are also present.

elements.content: Cu1 is pentacoordinated (Figure ), and the Addison parameter τ of 0.12 suggests that the coordination sphere around the copper atom adopts an almost ideal square pyramidal geometry, with one nitrogen atom and three oxygen atoms in basal positions and a nitrogen atom belonging to a terminal SCS molecule at the apex. The apical Cu1–N1 bond distance [2.237(5) Å] is markedly longer than the basal Cu1–N11 and Cu1–O bonds (around 2 Å). It is worth highlighting the equatorial coordination position of the water molecule, which is in contrast to the typical apical position in these kinds of environments in similar systems. There are also two uncoordinated oxygen atoms (O2 and O4) belonging to acetate ligands at longer Cu···O distances [3.042(4) Å and 3.191(5) Å for O2 and O4, respectively].

The apical Cu1-N1 bond distance [2.237(5) Å] is markedly longer than the basal Cu1-N11 and Cu1-O bonds (around 2 Å). elements.content: On the other hand, the Cu2 atom is in an elongated octahedral environment and exhibits the expected Jahn–Teller distortion (Figure ), with four short metal–ligand bonds (Cu–N and Cu–acetate) and two long bonds with water molecules [Cu2–O2W and Cu2–O1W with distances of 2.584(9) and 2.542(7) Å, respectively]. The configuration around this metal atom can be described in the CPI system as [OC-6-11]. The uncoordinated oxygen atoms of the acetate ligands are close to the metal center, with Cu···O distances of 3.052(9) Å (O32) and 3.161(10) Å (O22).

The configuration around this metal atom can be described in the CPI system as [OC-6-11]. The uncoordinated oxygen atoms of the acetate ligands are close to the metal center, with Cu⋅⋅⋅O distances of 3.052(9) Å (O32) and 3.161(10) Å (O22).

elements.content: For both metal centers, the acetate ligands can be considered as monodentate terminal ligands (κO) (Figure ) in trans positions but with different dispositions. For Cu2, the uncoordinated oxygen atoms are oriented to opposite sides of the line defined by O–Cu–O bonds, while around Cu1, they are directed to the same side (see Figure ).

elements.content: The usual bis-monodentate bridging (μ-κN:κN′) coordination mode of the SCS ligand is observed in three of the ligands, although the less common κN terminal mode is also present and this disrupts the polymerization of the compound.
elements.clean_text: The usual bis-monodentate bridging (μ-κN:κN') coordination mode of the SCS ligand is observed in three of the ligands, although the less common κN terminal mode is also present and this disrupts the polymerization of the compound.

elements.content: The three bridging SCS ligands have C–S–C–S torsion angles in the range 63.22°–73.56°, and this corresponds to a GG conformation (Table ). This torsion angle in the monodentate terminal ligand is higher (Table ) and is consistent with a TG conformation. In accordance with this situation, the intramolecular N···N distances are in the range 8.336–9.123 Å. This is the longest distance to the terminal ligand and leads to a Cu1···Cu2 distance of 11.8 Å and Cu2···Cu2 of 11.5 Å.

elements.content: The disposition of the terminal ligand and the unusual equatorial coordination position of the water molecule in the edge copper atoms (Cu1) allows the interaction between adjacent tetramers. The coordinated water molecules point toward the uncoordinated oxygen atoms of the acetate ligands (O2 and O4) (Figure , bottom), thus establishing Ow···O hydrogen-bonding interactions (Table ). The reciprocal interactions, which involve the same water molecule as a donor and the acetate oxygen atoms of a neighboring ligand as acceptors, lead to the formation of two eight-membered rings that form a stable strong set of interactions that result in a linear chain. The orientations of the terminal acetate ligands are also important to establish these interactions, and the terminal SCS disposition, which is opposite to that in the final arrangement, prevents participation in such interactions (Figure ).

elements.content: Water molecules (O2W, O1W) coordinated to central atoms (Cu2) and solvate water molecules establish different H-bonding interactions (Table ), which are responsible for the arrangement in the direction perpendicular to the tetramer. The uncoordinated pyridinic nitrogen atoms of the terminal SCS ligands are also involved in H-bonding interactions with the water molecules (O4W) to form the final 3D metallosupramolecular arrangement. These interactions seem to be strong enough to stabilize the acyclic oligomer over the cyclic or the polymeric structures even under the hydrothermal synthethic conditions. In this way, the molecules are less efficiently packed than those in 1, as shown by the calculated density of 1.550 g cm–3, but they are packed more efficiently than those in the solvate compound 2.

The structure of 4 is based on a one-dimensional polymeric neutral complex with crystallization water molecules. The polymer is formed by metallic nodes constituted by copper(II) tetramers with {Cu4(AcO)6(OH)2} cores containing two μ3-OH bridges and two SCS ligands that act as bridges between the nodes. We have previously found this structural motif during the study of the reactivity of formate and acetate copper(II) salts with 4,4′-dipyridyldisulfide (SS). The isolation of 4 reinforces the idea that the formation of this kind of tetrameric metallic node is favored with these building units. The two crystallographically independent copper(II) ions are hexacoordinated with different distorted octahedral geometries (Figure ). In both centers, the axial Cu–Ooco bond distances [2.772(4) Å in Cu(2)–O(42) and 2.778(3) Å in Cu(1)–O(41)] are longer than those found in the analogous SS compounds (distances of 2.637 and 2.655 Å). However, these distances are still shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of copper and oxygen. In this way, the Cu2 atoms are coordinated to one pyridine nitrogen atom from one SCS ligand, to two oxygen atoms from the two hydroxo bridges and to three oxygen atoms belonging to three different acetate ligands. However, the Cu1 center is coordinated to one pyridine nitrogen atom, one oxygen atom from a hydroxo bridge, and four oxygen atoms from three acetate ligands. For both metallic centers, the coordination geometry can be described as an axially elongated [4 + 1 + 1*] type. The acetate ligands have three different coordination modes: monodentate terminal (κO), bidentate bridging syn–syn (κO:κO′), and bidentate chelating-bridging syn–syn (κO,O′:κO:κO′).

Structural Study of Compound 4 

Selected structural parameters are listed in Table , and the main hydrogen-bonding parameters are listed in Table . The structure of 4 is based on a one-dimensional polymeric neutral complex with crystallization water molecules. The polymer is formed by metallic nodes constituted by copper(II) tetramers with {Cu4(AcO)6(OH)2} cores containing two μ3-OH bridges and two SCS ligands that act as bridges between the nodes. We have previously found this structural motif during the study of the reactivity of formate and acetate copper(II) salts with 4,4'-dipyridyldisulfide (SS). The isolation of 4 reinforces the idea that the formation of this kind of tetrameric metallic node is favored with these building units. The two crystallographically independent copper(II) ions are hexacoordinated with different distorted octahedral geometries (Figure ). In both centers, the axial Cu-Ooco bond distances [2.772(4) Å in Cu(2)-O(42) and 2.778(3) Å in Cu(1)-O(41)] are longer than those found in the analogous SS compounds (distances of 2.637 and 2.655 Å). However, these distances are still shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of copper and oxygen. In this way, the Cu2 atoms are coordinated to one pyridine nitrogen atom from one SCS ligand, to two oxygen atoms from the two hydroxo bridges and to three oxygen atoms belonging to three different acetate ligands. However, the Cu1 center is coordinated to one pyridine nitrogen atom, one oxygen atom from a hydroxo bridge, and four oxygen atoms from three acetate ligands. For both metallic centers, the coordination geometry can be described as an axially elongated [4 + 1 + 1*] type. The acetate ligands have three different coordination modes: monodentate terminal (κO), bidentate bridging syn-syn (κO:κO'), and bidentate chelating-bridging syn-syn (κO,O':κO:κO').

elements.content: The previously described compound [Cu4(HCO2)6(OH)2(SS)2] crystallized with dichloromethane molecules clathrated within the metallocyclic cavities. However, in 4 the crystallization water molecules that form 1D water chains are inserted into the interchain space (Figure ). The five crystallographically independent free water molecules are associated by Ow···Ow hydrogen bonds in an arrangement that can be defined as a C4 water chain ramified with two of the independent water molecules hanging perpendicularly to the direction of chain growth (Figure ). The Ow···Ow distances are in the range 2.852–2.909 Å. The water molecules are anchored by Ow···O hydrogen bonds (Table ) involving the oxygen of acetate. In this way, the water chains can be considered as the “glue” between the 1D metallorganic polymer to form the final 3D supramolecular arrangement, which is reinforced by the contribution of weak CH···Owater interactions (Table ). The potential solvent area per unit cell volume is 312 Å3, which represents 23.4% of the total crystal volume after removing water molecules from the model. The volume occupied by the solvent can be estimated by the corresponding values of the Kitaigorodskii packing index: 54.5% when the solvent is omitted and 67.3% when the solvent is included.

elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stability and Structural Changes

The TG analysis results show that all of the compounds (except 1) show similar weight loss behavior with two successive events (Figure S2, ), the release of the trapped solvent molecules followed by decomposition of the metal-organic framework.

elements.content: The thermogravimetric analysis of 1 only shows a weight loss when the compound begins to decompose at 195 °C. Thermal analysis of 2 shows that the first step starts at room temperature and continues to 100 °C, with a weight loss of 6% (calcd 3% for one molecule of water), and continues with a plateau until 135 °C. From this temperature to 210 °C, a second step with a weight loss of 17% is observed, which corresponds to the loss of the occluded dmf molecule (calcd 11%) and the beginning of the decomposition of the phase at approximately 190 °C. The weight loss temperature is in good agreement with the moderately weak interactions between the frameworks and the solvent molecules. The first weight loss is also assigned to the release of the trapped water molecules in 3 and 4. The TGA study of 3 shows a weight loss of 8.9% (calcd 8.7%) from rt to 100 °C, and the thermal analysis of 4 shows similar behavior, with a weight loss of 11% (calcd 11.7%) from rt to 100 °C. The next weight loss occurred at 145 °C (3) and 180 °C (4), when the metal–organic frameworks begin to decompose. This process continues until approximately 220 and 270 °C in 3 and 4, respectively.

elements.content: Compounds 1 and 2 are, respectively, the guest-free and the solvate forms of [Cu2(AcO)4(SCS)] n . It is possible to distinguish the two compounds by the shape of the crystals, which are green rectangular prisms in 1 and green thin sheets in 2 (Figure S3, ). The inclusion of solvent molecules in 2 led to the formation of the structurally different solvate crystallized in the C2/c space group (rt), whereas 1 belongs to the P1̅ space group (Scheme ) as described above. In this case, the presence of solvent molecules increases the symmetry in the lattice and reinforces the idea of the template role of the solvent in the structure. Consequently, we studied the solvation–desolvation process. It was found that the polymeric complex shows an irreversible transition from the monoclinic compound (2) to the triclinic compound (1) upon desolvation. The guest-free form can be obtained when a freshly ground sample of 2 is soaked in dichloromethane and dried at 80 °C for 24 h. Desolvation cannot be achieved only by heating the sample, and the treatment with dichloromethane proved to be essential. The desolvation of the sample was confirmed by IR spectroscopy and the XRPD pattern of the solvent-free sample compared with that of as-synthesized compound 2. The IR spectrum of the initial solid shows the characteristic band due to dimethylformamide. This band disappeared completely after treatment, and this suggests the successful removal of the solvent (Figure S4, ). The XRPD pattern of the original and desolvated samples showed that the desolvated material cannot maintain the framework after removal of the guest molecules (Figure S5, ). Nevertheless, it is possible to observe peaks that are consistent with the XRPD pattern calculated from the structure of 1. The removal of the solvents leads to a change in the twisted SCS ligand, and this in turn causes a structural rearrangement that leads to the formation of anhydrous 1 (Figure S6, ). However, it can be seen from this pair of structures how the inherent twist or shrink properties of the SCS ligand allows the adoption of different conformations. The flexibility of the SCS ligand is shown in the rotation about S–C(sp2) and S–C(sp3) bonds in the chain linking the two pyridine rings (Scheme ). The free rotation about each C–S bond gives rise to a degree of conformational diversity in the resulting coordination polymers, and the solvent of crystallization contributes to the range of solid-state structures produced. The structural changes involve three distinct stages: 2a at low temperature, 2b at room temperature, and 1, the desolvated phase. During the transformation, the product in each step has different cell parameters as a result of the rotation of the flexible twisted SCS linker.

The SCS linker acts like a “screw” to pull the voids open or shut through a twisting mechanism that only takes place on this ligand. Single crystal X-ray diffraction revealed that the bridge torsion angles change with the incorporation of different guest molecules, thus inducing the structural change. This ability to bend is reflected in the unusual anti conformation around the −S–C–S– group adopted by the pyridyl groups in 2a and 2b.

elements.content: Exposure of 1 to ethanol and dimethylformamide did not lead to the reabsorption of these solvents into the lattice, thus showing that this transformation is irreversible. Moreover, recrystallization of blue single crystals of 3 from ethanol led to a green solution containing the guest-free compound 1 (). This transformation was confirmed by X-ray powder diffraction experiments carried out before and after the treatment. Despite the loss of crystallinity, the pattern for the treated product closely matched that of the original compound 1 (Figure S7, ). This transformation may be related to the ethanol solvent used in the procedure. The low packing index of these structures could be indicative of the tendency of 2 and 3 to undergo structural transformations and the structural change to 1 suggests the energetic stability of the thermodynamically denser guest-free compound 1.

elements.content: Control of all the synthetic parameters allowed the isolation of pure phases of four new supramolecular isomers. The metal/linker ratio is important for the product distribution. The use of a 1:1 ratio led to 1D paddle-wheel polymers (1 and 2), whereas a 2:1 ratio led to the formation of a tetramer (3) or a double chain (4) depending on the solvent used. The coordination modes of the ligands seem to be the main factor that determines the different dimensionality of the compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Control of all the synthetic parameters allowed the isolation of pure phases of four new supramolecular isomers. The metal/linker ratio is important for the product distribution. The use of a 1:1 ratio led to 1D paddle-wheel polymers (1 and 2), whereas a 2:1 ratio led to the formation of a tetramer (3) or a double chain (4) depending on the solvent used. The coordination modes of the ligands seem to be the main factor that determines the different dimensionality of the compounds.

elements.content: The Cu2(AcO)4–(SCS)–Cu2(AcO)4 chain (1) possesses flexibility due to the bridging SCS ligand, and the supramolecular arrangement can be readily tailored by guest solvent molecules, as observed in 2. This flexibility could be responsible for pseudopolymorphism in the system as well as the structural diversity in the solvent inclusion compound 2, where the structure is greatly influenced by the size and shape of the guest molecules. Compound 2 exhibits a temperature-induced SC–SC transformation from an orthorhombic Pnma space group to a monoclinic C2/c space group through bending of the ligand. The removal of solvent molecules causes an irreversible structural transformation in which the symmetry is lowered to P1̅, which corresponds to the guest-free form of 1. This stable compound was also obtained from a solution of 3 in ethanol.

The removal of solvent molecules causes an irreversible structural transformation in which the symmetry is lowered to P1̅, which corresponds to the guest-free form of 1. This stable compound was also obtained from a solution of 3 in ethanol.

A solution of SCS (1 mmol) in methanol (10 mL) was added slowly to a suspension of Cu(AcO)2·H2O (1 mmol) in methanol (10 mL). The suspension was heated under reflux for 3 h. The resulting green precipitate was filtered off, washed with methanol, and dried under vacuum. Single crystals were obtained by slow evaporation at rt (1 week) of the mother liquor and also by slow diffusion in a test tube of a solution of SCS (0.25 mmol) in ethanol (3 mL) and a solution of Cu(AcO)2·H2O (0.5 mmol) in water (5 mL) at rt. The powder X-ray diffraction data were compared with those simulated from the crystal structure and showed that the crystal is representative of the bulk material. ResultsSynthesis and Spectroscopic Characterization

Four new compounds based on the Cu(II) acetate/SCS twisted N,N-ligand system were obtained by adjusting the synthetic conditions (Scheme ). Compounds were isolated from reactions carried out under mild conditions with 1:1 or 2:1 metal/ligand ratios using alcoholic solvents and water as the main solvents in four different synthetic methods, that is, under hydrothermal conditions (3), microwave irradiation (2), reflux synthesis (1), or slow diffusion in test tubes (4, 1, and 3).

Results

Synthesis and Spectroscopic Characterization

Four new compounds based on the Cu(II) acetate/SCS twisted N,N-ligand system were obtained by adjusting the synthetic conditions (Scheme ). Compounds were isolated from reactions carried out under mild conditions with 1:1 or 2:1 metal/ligand ratios using alcoholic solvents and water as the main solvents in four different synthetic methods, that is, under hydrothermal conditions (3), microwave irradiation (2), reflux synthesis (1), or slow diffusion in test tubes (4, 1, and 3).

In this way, the solvent filling the cavities plays the role of a template in the packing of compound 2. The potential solvent area of 1250 Å3 per unit cell volume, as calculated using PLATON, is 37% of the total crystal volume after removing solvent molecules from the model in 2b (1234 Å3, namely, 36.8% in 2a).

The previously described compound [Cu4(HCO2)6(OH)2(SS)2] crystallized with dichloromethane molecules clathrated within the metallocyclic cavities. However, in 4 the crystallization water molecules that form 1D water chains are inserted into the interchain space (Figure ). The five crystallographically independent free water molecules are associated by Ow···Ow hydrogen bonds in an arrangement that can be defined as a C4 water chain ramified with two of the independent water molecules hanging perpendicularly to the direction of chain growth (Figure ). The Ow···Ow distances are in the range 2.852–2.909 Å. The water molecules are anchored by Ow···O hydrogen bonds (Table ) involving the oxygen of acetate. In this way, the water chains can be considered as the “glue” between the 1D metallorganic polymer to form the final 3D supramolecular arrangement, which is reinforced by the contribution of weak CH···Owater interactions (Table ). The potential solvent area per unit cell volume is 312 Å3, which represents 23.4% of the total crystal volume after removing water molecules from the model. The volume occupied by the solvent can be estimated by the corresponding values of the Kitaigorodskii packing index: 54.5% when the solvent is omitted and 67.3% when the solvent is included.

The thermogravimetric analysis of 1 only shows a weight loss when the compound begins to decompose at 195 °C. Thermal analysis of 2 shows that the first step starts at room temperature and continues to 100 °C, with a weight loss of 6% (calcd 3% for one molecule of water), and continues with a plateau until 135 °C. From this temperature to 210 °C, a second step with a weight loss of 17% is observed, which corresponds to the loss of the occluded dmf molecule (calcd 11%) and the beginning of the decomposition of the phase at approximately 190 °C. The weight loss temperature is in good agreement with the moderately weak interactions between the frameworks and the solvent molecules. The first weight loss is also assigned to the release of the trapped water molecules in 3 and 4. The TGA study of 3 shows a weight loss of 8.9% (calcd 8.7%) from rt to 100 °C, and the thermal analysis of 4 shows similar behavior, with a weight loss of 11% (calcd 11.7%) from rt to 100 °C. The next weight loss occurred at 145 °C (3) and 180 °C (4), when the metal–organic frameworks begin to decompose. This process continues until approximately 220 and 270 °C in 3 and 4, respectively.
